{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3186186,"name":"","username":"mononaz","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/77aa72/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-11T13:33:08.291Z","cooked":"

Currently, our team is moving towards using only REV motors and motor controllers. However, with all the components in our CAN system, we have faced constant issues with the CAN bus and latency issues due to too many components on the daisy chain.

We are interested in implementing two separate CAN buses to solve this issue. One standard method I have seen to do this is with a CANivore; however, this device is not compatible with REV components, which is what we primarily use. I have also seen other teams use printed circuit boards (PCBs) to make their own CAN hub as another option. From the PCBs I have seen, they seem to be similar to a CANsplitter. As I was looking at other teams, I did not see many CANsplitters being used. As a result, I was wondering whether CANsplitters are a good solution for this issue, and if they are, why are they not used more frequently by other teams. I also want to ask whether there are other alternative methods we could use if the CANsplitter doesn’t work.

TLDR: Are CANSplitters a good solution to implement two CAN systems? If not, what are some other solutions?

Without using canivores, you can only have one can bus on the robot. With a can splitter, all the devices are still on the same can bus. If you have too many devices (CAN percentage is too high in the driverstation), you can reduce the frequency of some of the status frames that all your motor controllers put out.

With the currently existing products on the market, @Vasista is correct. The CANivore is for CTR products only, and as of 2023 firmware only for CAN-FD capable devices. A “CAN splitter” as some teams make is simply a wiring accessory; it does not electrically produce two distinct buses.

If you’re trying to keep bus utilization low, I wrote an article on status frame behavior that’s not fairly out of date but conveys the concepts okay.

Hopefully REV makes something clever for the 2024 season

There are currently no supported ways I know of to add REV hardware to a second CAN bus, Its unfortunatly not as simple as splitting the bus or finding a secondary CAN bus device.

The CAN splitters you’re talking about here only change the topology of the bus, this allows you to “branch” off your daisy chain, for short runs. FRC & the vendors strongly recommend using a dasiy chain.

We’re going to have to wait for REV to come out with a new hardware to give us a second bus. In the meantime you can use setControlFramePeriodMs​ & setPeriodicFramePeriod to change the rate of the CAN frames on the devices to reduce your bus utilization.

Sure they could get using a Spark Max as Socket CAN legal. OR, they could make usb control legal and I could rock a 20 port usb hub with an orange octopus coming out of it.
